title: VITAMIN B12: Overview, Uses, Side Effects, Precautions, Interactions, Dosing and Reviews
description: Learn more about VITAMIN B12 uses, effectiveness, possible side effects, interactions, dosage, user ratings and products that contain VITAMIN B12.
cleaned_text: Overview [Vitamin B12](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-926-vitamin+b12.aspx?activeingredientid=926&activeingredientname=vitamin+b12)is an essential vitamin found in foods such as meat, fish, and dairy. It can also be made in a lab and is often taken with other B vitamins. Vitamin B12 is required for the function and development of many parts of the body, including the [brain](www.webmd.com/brain/picture-of-the-brain-vue3), nerves, and [blood cells](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood). Methylcobalamin is the active form of vitamin B12. [Cyanocobalamin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1010/cyanocobalamin+(vitamin+b-12)+oral/details), which must be processed by the body into the active form, is the most common type used in [supplements](https://www.webmd.com/men/video/lamm-supplements-diet). People commonly use vitamin B12 for [vitamin B12 deficiency](https://www.webmd.com/diet/vitamin-b12-deficiency-symptoms-causes), cyanide poisoning, and high levels of [homocysteine](https://www.webmd.com/heart-disease/homocysteine-risk)in the blood. It is also used for [canker sores](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/canker-sores), [cataracts](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/cataracts/what-are-cataracts), [Alzheimer disease](https://www.webmd.com/alzheimers/understanding-alzheimers-disease-basics), [osteoporosis](https://www.webmd.com/osteoporosis/understanding-osteoporosis-basics), [fatigue](https://www.webmd.com/women/why-so-tired-10-causes-fatigue), and many other conditions, but there is no good scientific evidence to support most of these other uses. Uses & Effectiveness ? Effective for - A rare inherited condition marked by vitamin B12 deficiency (Imerslund-Grasbeck disease). Injecting vitamin B12 as a shot for 10 days followed by monthly injections is effective for treating this condition. Vitamin B12 shots can only be given by a [healthcare](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics)provider. - Vitamin B12 deficiency. Taking vitamin B12 by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/ss/slideshow-mouth-problems), as a shot, or inhaling through the nose can treat and prevent vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 shots can only be given by a [healthcare](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca)provider. Likely Effective for - Cyanide poisoning. Administering hydroxocobalamin (Cyanokit), a natural form of vitamin B12, as a shot is likely effective for treating cyanide poisoning. It has been approved by the US FDA for this use. Vitamin B12 shots can only be given by a healthcare provider. Possibly Effective for - Canker sores. Applying an ointment containing vitamin B12 or taking vitamin B12 under the [tongue](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/picture-of-the-tongue)seems to help reduce canker sore symptoms. - High levels of homocysteine in the blood (hyperhomocysteinemia). Taking vitamin B12 by [shingles](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/Shingles-Topic-Overview)(postherpetic neuralgia). Injecting vitamin B12 in the form of methylcobalamin under the [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/picture-of-the-skin)six times weekly for up to 4 weeks reduces pain in people with [nerve damage](https://www.webmd.com/brain/nerve-pain-and-nerve-damage-symptoms-and-causes)from [shingles](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/shingles/ss/slideshow-shingles-pictures). Vitamin B12 injections can only be given by a healthcare provider. Possibly Ineffective for - Decline in memory and thinking skills that occurs normally with age. Taking vitamin B12 by mouth, alone or with folic acid and vitamin B6, doesn't seem to improve mental function in elderly people. - Alzheimer disease. Taking vitamin B12 by mouth, alone or with folic acid and vitamin B6, doesn't seem to improve mental function in people with Alzheimer disease. [Cataracts](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/cataracts/ss/slideshow-cataracts). Taking vitamin B12 by mouth along with vitamin B6 and folic acid doesn't seem to prevent cataracts in females. It might even increase the risk of needing to have cataracts removed. - Disorders that affect when a person sleeps and when they are awake. Taking vitamin B12 by mouth does not seem to help people with [sleep disorders](https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/sleep-disorders-faq). - Decline in memory and thinking skills in older people that is more than what is normal for their age. Taking vitamin B12 by mouth, alone or with folic acid and vitamin B6, doesn't seem to improve memory and thinking skills in elderly people who have a decline in these skills. - Fall prevention. Taking folic acid with vitamin B12 by mouth doesn't seem to prevent falls in older people also taking [vitamin D](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-supplements/ingredientmono-929-vitamin+d.aspx?activeingredientid=929&activeingredientname=vitamin+d). - Weak and brittle bones (osteoporosis). Taking vitamin B12 and folic acid by mouth, with or without vitamin B6, doesn't seem to reduce [fractures](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-fractures-basic-information)in older people with osteoporosis. - Physical performance in elderly adults. Taking vitamin B12 and folic acid by mouth doesn't seem to help improve physical function in older people. Side Effects When applied to the skin: Vitamin B12 is likely safe for most people when used appropriately. When sprayed into the nose: Vitamin B12 is likely safe for most people. Vitamin B12 is considered safe even in large doses. Special Precautions and Warnings When applied to the skin: Vitamin B12 is likely safe for most people when used appropriately. When sprayed into the nose: Vitamin B12 is likely safe for most people. Vitamin B12 is considered safe even in large doses. Pregnancy and [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts)-feeding: Vitamin B12 is likely safe when taken by mouth during pregnancy or breast-feeding in the amounts recommended. The recommended amount for pregnancy is 2.6 mcg per day. Those breast-feeding should take 2.8 mcg per day. The safety of larger amounts is unknown. Post-surgical stent placement: Avoid using a combination of vitamin B12, folate, and vitamin B6 after receiving a coronary stent. This combination may increase the risk of blood vessel narrowing. [Allergy](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/video/truth-about-allergies)or sensitivity to cobalt or cobalamin: Do not use vitamin B12 if you have this condition. Interactions ? We currently have no information for VITAMIN B12 overview. Dosing People over 50 years of age are advised to eat foods fortified with vitamin B12 or to take a vitamin B12 supplement. 25-100 mcg daily has been taken by mouth to maintain vitamin B12 levels in older adults.
